title: 3D tracking of ferrous iron in the epileptic mouse brain and screening of iron homeostasis regulators with a two-photon fluorescent probe
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparing plates for culturing mouse hippocampal neurons
Timing: (Day 0) 5 h
Timing: 5 h at day 0
The protocol below describes the specific steps to prepare plates for mouse hippocampal neurons (see details in troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]).
Note: The steps must be performed in a biosafety cabinet.
Preparing plates coated with Poly-D-lysine.
Sterilize distilled water using a syringe filter with a 0.22 μm pore size.
Dilute Poly-D-lysine in distilled water to 50 mg/mL (molecular weight: 150,000–300,000), and store at 4°C for up to 1 week.
Add 50 μL of the diluted Poly-D-lysine solution to each well of a 96-well culture plate (flat and clear bottom; black side).
Incubate at 37°C for at least 4 h.
Aspirate the Poly-D-lysine solution and rinse the plate at least three times with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS).
Dry the 96-well plate in the biosafety cabinet for later use in a week.
Critical: After removing the Poly-D-lysine coating solution, wash the plates at least three times with PBS rather than dry directly because PDL is very toxic and might kill the neurons. A 96-well culture plate needs about 4.8 mL of Poly-D-lysine solution (50 mg/mL).
Isolation and culture of hippocampal neurons
Timing: (Day 1) 11 h
Timing: 6 h at Day 1
Timing: 5 h at day 1
Timing: 10 min at Day 1, 30 min at Day 4, 30 min at Day 7
The protocol below describes the specific steps to culture mouse hippocampal neurons for screening drugs that can regulate iron homeostasis (see details in troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]).
Isolation of mouse hippocampal neurons.
Prepare a dissecting microscope, sterilized fine tweezers, scissors, 100-mm culture dishes, and 15 mL centrifuge tubes.
Prepare female BALB/c mice at 18–20 days of pregnancy.

Prepare 75% ethanol, pre-cooled Hanks’ Balanced Salt Solution without Ca2+ and Mg2+ (HBSS), high glucose DMEM, 0.25% trypsin (containing 0.1% EDTA), Recombinant DNase I (RNase-free), heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS, 56°C for 30 min with shaking every 5 min).
Sacrifice a mouse by cervical dislocation after deep anesthetization with 1.5%–2% isoflurane.
Immerse the mouse in 75% ethanol for 2–5 s and place on ice to lower body temperature to 0°C as fast as possible.
While keeping the mouse at low temperature (working on ice or an ice pad), dissect the mouse, find the placenta, and put it into the pre-cooled soaking solution (HBSS without Ca2+ and Mg2+) in a 100-mm culture dish.
Carefully remove the embryo brains one by one and place them into another 100-mm culture dish with cold HBSS (without Ca2+ and Mg2+).
Isolate the entire hippocampal region of the mouse under a dissecting microscope as much as possible.
Carefully remove all blood vessels and membranes on the hippocampal tissue surface using fine tweezers.
Transfer the hippocampal tissue into another culture dish with pre-cooled sterile serum-free high glucose DMEM.
Wash three times with serum-free high glucose DMEM.
Cut the hippocampal tissue into 1–2 mm fragments with sterile scissors.
Carefully remove the supernatant.
Add 1.5 mL trypsin and 30 μL Recombinant DNase I (RNase-free) to the hippocampal tissue and incubate at 37°C.
Shake every 2 min for three times.
Transfer the digested tissue to a 15 mL centrifuge tube, then add 3 mL of 10% inactivated FBS-containing complete medium to terminate trypsin digestion.
Centrifuge at 319 × g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in complete medium.
Centrifuge at 319 × g for 5 min to remove the supernatant again.
Add 2 mL of complete medium, and slowly pipette 10 times.

After standing for 5 min, remove 1.5 mL of the supernatant, and place it in another centrifuge tube.
Add 1.5 mL complete medium and pipette 10 times.
After standing for 5 min, transfer 1.5 mL of the supernatant to the same centrifuge tube in step u.
Add 1.5 mL complete medium again, pipette 10 times.
After standing for 5 min, transfer 1.5 mL of the supernatant to the same centrifuge tube in steps u and w.
Centrifuge the centrifuge tube containing a total of 4.5 mL cell suspension for 10 min at 319 × g.
Culture of mouse hippocampal neurons.
Prepare the plating medium: 10% heated-inactivated FBS, 0.5% penicillin-streptomycin, high glucose DMEM.
Prepare the growth medium: 500 μM L-Glut, 2% B27 Plus, 0.5% penicillin-streptomycin, Neurobasal Plus.
Remove the supernatant from step 1z, resuspend the pellet of neuron cells in the plating medium, count the cells and adjust to a final concentration of 2×104/mL with the plating medium.
Plate 100 μL of the neuron cell suspension into each well of a 96-well plate that has been pre-coated with Poly-D-lysine.
Place the 96-well plate in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 4 h.
Replace the plating medium with a growth medium completely.
Replace half of the growth medium every three days.
Culture hippocampal neurons for at least one week before using them for subsequent experiments.
Alternatives: The steps listed above are methods that we have used to successfully culture mature neurons, but they could be substituted by similar protocols.
Monitoring the maturation of neurons.
(Day 1, 10 min) Check the adherent state of hippocampal neurons in the growth medium.
(Day 4, 30 min) Replace half of the culture medium with fresh medium.
Note: Exclude L-Glut when making the fresh culture medium. Check the status of neurite outgrowth (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

(Day 7, 30 min) Replace half of the culture medium with fresh medium.
Note: Exclude L-Glut when making the fresh culture medium. Observe the neurite outgrowth (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Optional: To ensure the successful culture of mature neurons, immunofluorescence staining of synapsin could be used. An abundance of synapsin-positive puncta per neuron should be observed in mature neuronal cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Employing drug treatment to modulate iron homeostasis
Timing: (Day 9–10) 1 h at Day 9, 30 min at Day 10
Note: In all steps, pre-warm the hippocampal neuron culture medium, PBS, and HBSS at 37°C to avoid cold stimulation of the neurons. Perform steps 5–7 in a biosafety cabinet.
(Day 9, 30 min) Treatment of hippocampal neurons with kainic acid.
Make sure the neurons are mature enough before use.
Discard the medium.
Add fresh medium with 500 μM kainic acid.
Incubate at 37°C under 5% CO2 for 12 h.
(Day 9, 30 min) Treatment of hippocampal neurons with different natural products.
Discard the medium.
Wash with PBS twice.
Add fresh medium with 20 μM of different natural products.
Incubate at 37°C under 5% CO2 for 12 h.
(Day 10, 30 min) Incubation of hippocampal neurons with fluorescence probes of Fe2+ and the nucleus.

Note: We would like to promote the use of specific target probes for high-throughput screening of reported active compounds rather than being limited to a few natural products covered in this protocol. If readers have more natural product library resources, they can use the FeP or other Fe2+ probe and methods provided in this protocol to expand screening.
Discard the medium.
Wash the cells twice with PBS.
Add 100 uL fresh medium with 5 μg/mL Hoechst 33342 and 10 μM FeP.
Incubate at 37°C under 5% CO2 for 30 min.
Discard the medium.
Wash with PBS twice.
Add 50 μL HBSS and proceed to high-content analysis.
Setting up the protocol for the high-content analysis
Timing: (Day 10) 2 h
The protocol below describes the method for the measurement of Fe2+ flux in the Columbus Image Data Storage and Analysis System (see details in troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]).
(Day 10, 2 h) Fluorescence image acquisition.
Turn on the high-content screening (HCS) machine (PerkinElmer Operetta CLS) 30 min before use.
Place the 96-well culture plates into the HCS machine.
Choose a normal-focus 40× magnification lens.
Set a combination of 380 nm excitation wavelength and emission filter 525/15 in channel 1 for Hoechst 33342.
Set a combination of 475 nm excitation wavelength and emission filter 615/15 in channel 2 for FeP.
Set the optimal exposure time for all channels.
Adjust the best focal length.
Set 10 fields of view per well.
Set the parameters of the living cell studio at 37°C and 5% CO2.
Start scanning.
Note: Approximately 400 cells per well are imaged.
Analysis of Fe2+ flux with FeP
Timing: (Day 10) ∼1 h

This section describes a method for analyzing the fluorescence intensity mediated by Fe2+ flux per body part of neurons area from the images captured by FeP over the number of Hoechst-positive objects.
(Day 10, ∼1 h) Set up the measurement protocol of Columbus Image Data Storage and Analysis System software as follows (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4], 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5], 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6], 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7], and 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
Note: To avoid interference from the intricate connections between neurons, we only measured fluorescence in the cell body of each neuron.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 9.a”) to detect neurons.
Note: Set stack processing as the maximum intensity projection. Set flatfield correction as basic mode. Adjust the contrast of two channels until the contrast between the body of neurons and background is clear and the image is not overexposed, respectively.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 9.b”) to detect neuronal nuclei from images of neurons stained by Hoechst 33342.
Note: Set the method as B mode: common threshold as 0.4, area > 30 μm2, output population as nuclei.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 9.c”) to detect neuronal cytoplasm from images of neurons stained by FeP based on identified nuclei.
Note: Set the method as A mode: common threshold as 0.15.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 9.d”) to analyze the images of FeP fluorescence staining captured in 9.c.
Note: Set channel as FeP, the population as nuclei, the region as whole-cell, method as standard, output properties as “Intensity Cell FeP Mean”.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 9.e”) to define the results analyzed in step 9.d.

Note: Choose method as standard out. Export the intensity cell FeP mean value from the analysis results as an Excel file, which represents the content of Fe2+ per cell. If necessary, download the value of the number of objects, which represents the number of neurons analyzed.

Stereotactic surgery
Timing: (Day 11) Duration of the surgery is 30 min for each mouse at Day 11
The protocol below describes how to perform stereotactic surgery to implant EEG-EMG electrodes in mice and investigate the potential antiepileptic effects of the DHA.
Note: Since the wound is hermetically sealed by dental cement, post-operational analgesics and antibiotics were not used. These mice are allowed to recover for one week after surgery.
(Day 11, 20 h) Prepare mice for stereotactic EEG-EMG electrodes surgery.
Anesthetize mice by using isoflurane. The induction and maintenance doses of isoflurane are 3% and 1.5%–2%.
Disinfect stainless steel screws (used as electrodes) with 75% alcohol, wash with PBS, and finally blot with absorbent paper.

Place the stainless steel screws on top of the dura mater through small holes drilled in the skull with a high-speed drill.
Implant a total of five electrodes. Place the front two electrodes over the motor cortex (approximately 1 mm anterior to bregma and 1.5 mm lateral to the midline).
Place the other two electrodes approximately 1.5 mm anterior to lambda and 1.5 mm lateral to the midline.
Place the ground electrode in the midline approximately 1.5 mm posterior of lambda (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]).

Figure 9. Surgical procedures for the implantation of recording electrodes
(A) The in-kind real shoot of the electrode adaptor.
(B) Small openings marked on the skull that allow electrode insertion.
In the process, hold the electrode still with a tweezer using the left hand, and turn the screw with a screwdriver with the right hand slowly until it passes through the skull (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1808-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Surgical procedures for the implantation of recording electrodes and dental cement fixation
Fix the stainless steel screws to the skull by using dental cement.
Wire EEG-EMG electrodes to the head mount.
Fix the head mount to the skull by using dental cement.
Optional: Although EEG-EMG electrodes are used in this protocol, only the EEG signal is relevant and it also works if only EEG electrodes are implanted for recording. The EMG signal is just a reference to determine whether mice are asleep or awake.
Video-EEG-EMG monitoring
Timing: (Day 12–22) The duration of mice recovery is 7 days from Day 11 to Day 18, 1 h at Day 19, 30 min at Day 20, 30 min at Day 21
This section describes the steps to prepare the mice for video-EEG-EMG recording.
(Day 11–18, 7 days) Recovery from electrode implantation surgery.

Place mice into the stereotactic apparatus for surgical implantation of electrodes. After surgery, return mice into the home cage and allow them to recover for one week (see section Stereotaxic surgery).
(Day 19–21, 2 h) Establishment of an epileptic mouse model and DHA treatment. Treat mice with DHA to establish epileptic mouse models as detailed in Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]:
Dilute the stock solution of DHA to 6 mg/mL with PBS to prepare the working solution. The final injection solvent of DHA is DMSO-PBS buffer (10 mM, pH 7.4, 1:9, v/v).
Inject mice with DHA (60 mg/kg) via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
Dilute the stock solution of kainic acid to 4 mg/mL with PBS to prepare the working solution.
Inject mice with KA (20 mg/kg) via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
(Day 21–22, 10 h) Video-EEG-EMG recording (see details in troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).

Place each mouse into a 21 cm × 19 cm transparent cage individually.
Insert a pre-amplifier into the 8-pin head cap and connect to a multichannel commutator (Bio-Signal Technologies).
Adjust EEG-EMG signals at 500 Hz and bandpass filtered at 1–100 Hz.
Adjust recording of videos as 10 frames/s.
Record EEG-EMG signals and synchronized videos by using the Athena system (Bio-Signal Technologies) for 2 h.
Use Sirenia Seizure Pro (Pinnacle Technology) to analyze the whole course EEG-EMG recordings and representative traces.
Analyze the EEG signals for electrographic seizure events.
Note: Seizure events were defined as high amplitudes at two-fold of the baseline and durations lasting at least 10 s, using the Sirenia Seizure Pro software (Pinnacle Technology Inc, Lawrence, KS).

Analysis of mouse brain EEG signals using Sirenia Seizure Pro software
Timing: (Day 22 or later)
This section describes a method to analyze the EEG-based data offline by using Sirenia Seizure Pro software. The advanced analysis generated by Sirenia Seizure Pro software provides user-configured parameters for conveniently analyzing seizure events over a given time period.
(Day 22 or later, ∼6 h) Set up the measurement protocol of Sirenia Seizure Pro software as follows (Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12], Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13], Figure 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig14], Figure 15[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig15], Figure 16[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig16], and Figure 17[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig17]).
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.a”) to read EEG-EMG recordings in EDF format.
Note: The BIO file of the whole course EEG-EMG recordings is converted to a standard format of EDF and imported into the Sirenia Seizure Pro software for analysis.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.b”) to generate the custom plot.
Note: Set the "freq" fields from 0.1 to 100 Hz at the high pass type and click on the" Apply Filter" button to filter the setting, and choose a suitable period. We get used to analyzing 1 h of raw EEG data as a suitable period. The analyzed period choosing based on your collected data generally.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.c”) to consolidate and extract data from all channels.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.d”) to select seizures.
Note: Extract the features from an obvious seizure (Seizures were defined by a rapid and rhythmic spiking activity (>3 Hz) that persisted for >5 s with high amplitudes (>2× baseline level). Here, we didn't distinguish different types of seizure.) as a pattern-matching template in this experiment by the seizure selection tool. Then, click on the" Add type" button to place the event and feature set into a pattern-matching database.

Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.e”) to find all seizures.
Note: Adjust the search setting to match patterns with features extracted in step d and identify similar seizures in the whole EEG. Pattern matching includes, but is not limited to, RMS power, frequency band, amplitude, and line length.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.f”) to mark all seizures.
Note: Please have three experienced researchers confirm the EEG seizure events after sorting by the software. All the matched seizures can be rejected, accepted, or merged with nearby events to better classify seizures.
Create an analysis protocol (termed “step 14.g”) to export the data for human review and analysis.
Note: Analyze data on amplitude during seizures, seizure duration, line length, and total EEG power during seizures based on the entire EEG.

In vivo fluorescence imaging
Timing: (Day 22–25)
The protocol below describes the steps for in vivo fluorescent imaging of drug-treated epileptic mice.
(Day 22–24, 2 h) Treat mice with DHA to establish epileptic models as described in step 12. Then, perform global imaging of the whole body by using the IVIS Spectrum imaging system.

Dilute the stock solution of DHA to 6 mg/mL with PBS (10% DMSO) to prepare the working solution.
Inject DHA (60 mg/kg) into mice via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
Dilute the stock solution of kainic acid to 1.2 mg/mL with PBS to prepare the working solution.
Inject mice with kainic acid (6 mg/kg) via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
(Day 23–25, 2 h) Treat the new mice with DHA to establish epileptic models as in step 12. Then, perform local imaging in the primary somatomotor cortex by using a confocal fluorescent microscope (ZEISS LSM 980 with Airyscan).
Dilute the stock solution of DHA to 6 mg/mL with PBS (10% DMSO) to prepare the working solution.
Inject DHA (60 mg/kg) into mice via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
Dilute the stock solution of kainic acid to 4 mg/mL with PBS to prepare the working solution.
Inject kainic acid (20 mg/kg) into mice via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
(Day 24, 6 h) The whole body imaging using the IVIS Spectrum imaging system (Figure 18[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig18]).
Note: The average radiant efficiency of a good picture is at least on the order of 107 p/sec/cm2/sr/(μW/cm2). The duration to detect the fluorescent depends on the metabolic process of the probe and there will be differences between different probes. The peak of dots per inch fluorescent intensity FeP in mice was 30 min, so we performed fluorescence tracking at different time points within 1 h.
Dilute the stock solution of FeP to 0.1 mg/mL with PBS (5% DMSO) to prepare the working solution.
Inject FeP (0.5 mg/kg) into mice via intravenous (i.v.) injection (see details in troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Anesthetize mice with 1.5%–2% isoflurane.
Set the excitation filter and collection wavelength range of IVIS Lumina XR in vivo imaging system as 465 nm and 575–650 nm, and choose “Auto Exposure”.

Capture fluorescence images at 5, 15, 30, 45, and 60 min post-injection of FeP.
(Day 25, 8 h) Local imaging using a confocal fluorescent microscope (ZEISS LSM 980 with Airyscan).
Note: The body temperature of mice is maintained with an electric heating blanket during the entire surgery-imaging procedure.
Sterilize all surgical materials (including forceps, scissors, drills, and glass coverslips).
Warm up the confocal fluorescent microscope (ZEISS LSM 980 with Airyscan) for 30 min.
Set the excitation filter and collection wavelength range as two-photon 880 nm and 600–680 nm (Figure 19[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig19]A).
Note: the power of imaging light is less than 15%, and the master gain is less than 800.
Anesthetize mice with 1.5%–2% isoflurane or 2% pentobarbital sodium.
Place the mouse in a stereotaxic frame.
Disinfect the scalp with 75% ethanol.
Cut the scalp with a scalpel and scissors and avoid damaging blood vessels, carefully remove the muscles and periosteum to guarantee access to the cranium.
Note: If occasional minor bleeding occurs, stop the bleeding by applying pressure with medical cotton tips not touching the brain surface immediately, and then dip a small amount of warm PBS to gently wipe away the blood.
By careful drilling, thin the skull in a circular pattern until it is almost detached.
Remove the skull with fine forceps.
Dilute the FeP stock solution with PBS (5% DMSO) to 0.1 mg/mL to prepare the working solution. Inject FeP (0.5 mg/kg) into mice by intravenous (i.v.) injection.
Move the 20× hydroscope lens to the cerebral cortex of the left lateral ventricle, corresponding to the primary somatomotor cortex (Economo et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]) (Wang et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]) (Figure 19[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig19]B).
Capture fluorescence images with laser-laminar scanning every 5 min for 1 h (Figure 20[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig20]).

Preparing brain slices for fluorescence imaging
Timing: (Day 26) 3.5 h
The protocol below describes the steps for preparing brain slices.
(Day 26, 3.5 h) Prepare the brain slices.
Pre-cool the freezing microtome to −20°C.
After injecting inject mice with FeP through the tail vein for 1 h; sacrifice mice by cervical dislocation after deep anesthetization with 1.5%–2% isoflurane.
Dissect out the brain and flash freeze in liquid nitrogen (see details in troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.11]).
Embed the frozen brain at the Optimal Cutting Temperature (O.C.T.).
Place the embedded brain tissue in the freezing microtome for sectioning.
Dry the slices and store them at −80°C for use.
Brain slices fluorescence imaging
Timing: (Day 26) 8 h
This protocol below describes the steps for preparing the brain slices of mice for fluorescence imaging.
(Day 26, 8 h) Staining and fluorescence imaging.
Take out the brain slices from the ultra-low temperature freezer.
Return slices to 25°C.
Dry for 30 min before staining.
Dilute DAPI stock solution to 10 μg/mL with PBS to prepare the working solution.
Use liquid blocker super PAP Pen to form a stable hydrophobic isolation zone surrounding tissue samples.
Stain with DAPI for 30 min at 37°C.
Warm up the two-photon laser of the confocal fluorescent microscope (Leica TCS SP8 MP) for 1 h.

Set the fluorescence excitation filter and emission window as MP 880 nm and 600–680 nm for FeP. Set the fluorescence excitation filter and emission window as 405 nm and 420–480 nm for DAPI.
Choose the scan selected area in the XY stage to determine the boundaries of the hippocampus.
Capture individual MP fluorescence images in sequence.
Join all images of the multi-photon together into the maximum hippocampal surface in brain tissues by Leica TCS SP8 MP (Figure 21[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig21]).
